meanings.def: either of the two halves of a surface, an object or an area that is divided by an imaginary central line
examples: the right side of the brain
satellite links to the other side of the world
on the… side (of something) They drive on the left-hand side of the road in Japan.
She was on the far side of the room.
They crossed from one side of London to the other.
Keep on your side of the bed!
a factory on the west side of town
A car was coming in their direction on the wrong side of the road.
She got in the passenger side of the car.
the left-hand side of the page
the sunny, leeward side of the island

meanings.def: a position or an area to the left or right of something
examples: He crossed the bridge to the other side of the river.
The opposite side of the street was still in shadow.
on a/the side (of something) There is a large window on either side of the front door.
people on both sides of the Atlantic
a town on this side of the border
She saw James standing on the other side of the fence.
She tilted her head to one side.

meanings.def: one of the flat surfaces of something that is not the top or bottom, front or back
examples: A notice was stuck to the side of the filing cabinet.
on the side (of something) Write your name on the side of the box.
There's a scratch on the side of my car.
Now lay the jar on its side.
The ship was damaged on her starboard side.
at the side (of something) The kitchen door is at the side of the house.
a side door/window/panel
a side wall/entrance

meanings.def: the vertical or sloping surface around something, but not the top or bottom of it
examples: A path went up the side of the hill.
Brush the sides of the tin with butter.
We could see sheep grazing on the side of the mountain.

meanings.def: a part near the edge of something; an area just beyond the edge of something
examples: The stream flows into the south side of the lake.
A path leads down one side of the garden.
We planted tulips along the side of the lawn.
on the side of something She sat on the side of the bed.
The player received treatment on the side of the pitch.
at the side of something A van was parked at the side of the road.

meanings.def: either the right or left part of a person’s body, from the armpit (= where the arm joins the body) to the hip (= where the leg joins the body)
examples: I've got a stitch in my side (= a sudden pain from running or laughing).
She has a pain down her right side.
on your side He was lying on his side.
Emily turned onto her side and yawned.
He is paralysed down his left side as a result of polio.
I always sleep on my side because I'm not comfortable on my back.
I laughed until my sides ached.

meanings.def: either of two surfaces of something flat and thin, such as paper or cloth
examples: The upper side of the leaf was a much darker green.
The reverse side of the coin has a picture of a flower.
on a/the side (of something) Write on one side of the paper only.
Fry the steaks for two minutes on each side.

meanings.def: the amount of writing needed to fill one side of a sheet of paper
examples: He told us not to write more than three sides.

meanings.def: any of the flat surfaces of a solid object
examples: A cube has six sides.
Each side of the pyramid is greater than five acres in area.

meanings.def: any of the lines that form a flat shape such as a square or triangle
examples: a shape with five sides
The farm buildings form three sides of a square.

meanings.def: used in adjectives to state the number or type of sides
examples: a six-sided object
a glass-sided container

meanings.def: a place or position very near to somebody/something
examples: at/by somebody's/something's side Her husband stood at her side.
She was glad to have him by her side.
Keep close to my side.
Her friends never seem to leave her side.
He rushed to be at her side.

meanings.def: one of the two or more people or groups taking part in an argument, war, etc.
examples: Both sides agreed to restore diplomatic relations.
At some point during the war he seems to have changed sides.
Each side is capable of destroying the other in a nuclear war.
We have finally reached an agreement acceptable to all sides.
The two sides announced a deal yesterday.
on the… side to be on the winning/losing side
There are faults on both sides.
There is anger on both sides of the political divide.
Each side accused the other of firing first.
He switched sides and joined the opposition.
Let both sides argue their case.
There were casualties on both sides of the conflict.
War forces people to choose sides.
The other side maintains that the project will not be affordable.

meanings.def: one of the opinions, attitudes, or positions held by somebody in an argument, a business arrangement, etc.
examples: We heard both sides of the argument.
I just want you to hear my side of the story first.
One side of the debate is articulated best by France and Germany.
The defendant has had no opportunity to put his side of the case.
Will you keep your side of the bargain?
on the… side On the plus side, the film is beautifully shot and edited.

meanings.def: a particular aspect of something, especially a situation or a person’s character
examples: These poems reveal her gentle side.
It's interesting to see another side of a story that is so well known.
It's good you can see the funny side of the situation.
I'll take care of that side of things.
This is a side of Alan that I never knew existed.
the darker side of human nature
a behind-the-scenes documentary which promises to show a side of him rarely seen in public
Bob is hoping to show off his lighter side.
He's usually very kind and gentle, but he has his less positive side too.
She likes men who do not hide their feminine side.
The scandal has shown us the ugly side of politics.
This murder highlights the seamy side of Hollywood.
There are several sides to most problems.
I had nothing to do with the financial side of the company.
What can we do on the supply side to make this market more competitive?

meanings.def: a feeling that you are better than other people
examples: There was no side to him at all.

meanings.def: a sports team
examples: As captain, Pryce is confident of leading his side to victory.
The French have a very strong side.
We were on the winning/losing side.
As the home side, they were expected to play an attacking game.
His side conceded two goals in their last match.
Cain's goal put his side ahead.
The away side were dismissed for 192.
An inexperienced English side overcame a determined home team 39–24.
He scored the winning goal in the famous 2016 cup-winning side.
Wenger is planning to field an unchanged side for the second leg.
Both sides struggled to find any sort of form.

meanings.def: the part of your family that people belong to who are related either to your mother or to your father
examples: a cousin on my father’s side (= a child of my father’s brother or sister)

meanings.def: a side dish (= a small amount of food, for example a salad, served with the main course of a meal)
examples: Your dinner comes with a choice of two sides.

meanings.def: one of the two halves of an animal that has been killed for meat
a television channel
examples: What's on the other side?

meanings.def: to support and agree with somebody
examples: I'm definitely on your side in this.
Whose side are you on anyway?

meanings.def: the boyfriend or girlfriend of somebody who is already married or in a steady sexual relationship with somebody else
examples: Is he your bit on the side?

meanings.def: to choose between two possible choices
to show too much of a good quality in order to avoid showing too little
examples: I thought it was better to err on the side of caution (= to be too careful rather than take a risk).

meanings.def: moving to the left and then to the right and then back again
examples: He shook his head slowly from side to side.
The ship rolled from side to side.
The cat sat with its tail twitching from side to side.

meanings.def: from or living in a poor area or part of town
to make somebody pleased with you/annoyed with you
to be in a bad mood for the whole day for no particular reason
said about people who never seem happy with what they have and always think they could be happier in a different place or situation
to have something as an advantage that will make it more likely that you will achieve something
examples: She may not win this year, but she does have youth on her side.

meanings.def: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself
to be forced to change from feeling pleased or satisfied to feeling disappointed or annoyed
examples: He’ll be laughing on the other side of his face when he reads my letter.

meanings.def: to fail to give your friends, family, etc. the help and support they expect, or to behave in a way that makes them disappointed
examples: You can always rely on Maggie—she’d never let the side down.
I felt I was letting the side down by not going to the wedding.

meanings.def: to be cheerful or positive about a bad situation, for example by thinking only of the advantages and not the disadvantages
examples: Look on the bright side. You managed to do more than I did.

meanings.def: to stay with somebody, especially in order to take care of them
in or from all directions; everywhere
examples: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.

meanings.def: slightly too big, small, high, etc.
examples: These shoes are a little on the tight side.
Don’t you think you’re a bit on the short side to play basketball?

meanings.def: used to introduce the good points about somebody/something, especially after the bad points have been mentioned
examples: On the credit side, she’s always willing to work very late.

meanings.def: on the woman’s side of the family
out of your way
examples: I left my bags on one side.

meanings.def: to be dealt with later
examples: I put his complaint to one side until I had more time.
Leaving that to one side for a moment, are there any other questions?

meanings.def: younger or older than 40, 50, etc. years of age
being especially careful; taking no risks
examples: I took some extra cash just to be on the safe side.

meanings.def: in addition to your main job
examples: a mechanic who buys and sells cars on the side

meanings.def: secretly or illegally
examples: He's married but he has a girlfriend on the side.

meanings.def: served at the same time as the main part of the meal, but on a separate plate
in trouble with the police
the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about
with the top part turned to the top; in the correct, normal position
examples: I dropped my toast, but luckily it fell right side up.

meanings.def: close together and facing in the same direction
examples: There were two children ahead, walking side by side.
The two sat side by side on the bench.

meanings.def: together, without any difficulties
examples: We have been using both systems, side by side, for two years.
The two communities exist happily side by side.

meanings.def: used to refer to either of two opposite opinions on an issue
examples: The two countries are often on opposite sides of the fence when it comes to climate change.
There are arguments on both sides of the aisle.
On the other side of the fence there is anger at the reforms.
It is a proposal approved by people on both sides of the political fence.

meanings.def: to laugh a lot at somebody/something
to express support for somebody in an argument
examples: She didn't think it was wise to take sides in their argument.

meanings.def: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something
before a particular time, event, age, etc.
examples: They aren't likely to arrive this side of midnight.

meanings.def: a person or thing that repeatedly annoys somebody or stops them from doing something
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something
used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation

idioms.def: to support and agree with somebody
examples: I'm definitely on your side in this.
Whose side are you on anyway?

idioms.def: the boyfriend or girlfriend of somebody who is already married or in a steady sexual relationship with somebody else
examples: Is he your bit on the side?

idioms.idiom: come down on one side of the fence or the other
idioms.def: to choose between two possible choices

idioms.idiom: err on the side of something
idioms.def: to show too much of a good quality in order to avoid showing too little
examples: I thought it was better to err on the side of caution (= to be too careful rather than take a risk).

idioms.def: moving to the left and then to the right and then back again
examples: He shook his head slowly from side to side.
The ship rolled from side to side.
The cat sat with its tail twitching from side to side.

idioms.idiom: from/on the wrong side of the tracks
idioms.def: from or living in a poor area or part of town

idioms.idiom: get on the right/wrong side of somebody
idioms.def: to make somebody pleased with you/annoyed with you

idioms.idiom: get out of bed on the wrong side
idioms.def: to be in a bad mood for the whole day for no particular reason

idioms.idiom: the grass is (always) greener on the other side (of the fence)
idioms.def: said about people who never seem happy with what they have and always think they could be happier in a different place or situation
to have something as an advantage that will make it more likely that you will achieve something
examples: She may not win this year, but she does have youth on her side.

idioms.idiom: know which side your bread is buttered
idioms.def: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself

idioms.idiom: laugh on the other side of your face
idioms.def: to be forced to change from feeling pleased or satisfied to feeling disappointed or annoyed
examples: He’ll be laughing on the other side of his face when he reads my letter.

idioms.def: to fail to give your friends, family, etc. the help and support they expect, or to behave in a way that makes them disappointed
examples: You can always rely on Maggie—she’d never let the side down.
I felt I was letting the side down by not going to the wedding.

idioms.def: to be cheerful or positive about a bad situation, for example by thinking only of the advantages and not the disadvantages
examples: Look on the bright side. You managed to do more than I did.

idioms.def: to stay with somebody, especially in order to take care of them

idioms.idiom: on/from all sides | on/from every side
idioms.def: in or from all directions; everywhere
examples: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.

idioms.idiom: on the big, small, high, etc. side
idioms.def: slightly too big, small, high, etc.
examples: These shoes are a little on the tight side.
Don’t you think you’re a bit on the short side to play basketball?

idioms.def: used to introduce the good points about somebody/something, especially after the bad points have been mentioned
examples: On the credit side, she’s always willing to work very late.

idioms.def: on the woman’s side of the family
out of your way
examples: I left my bags on one side.
I put his complaint to one side until I had more time.
Leaving that to one side for a moment, are there any other questions?

idioms.idiom: on the right/wrong side of 40, 50, etc.
idioms.def: younger or older than 40, 50, etc. years of age
being especially careful; taking no risks
examples: I took some extra cash just to be on the safe side.

idioms.def: in addition to your main job
examples: a mechanic who buys and sells cars on the side
He's married but he has a girlfriend on the side.

idioms.idiom: on the wrong side of the law
idioms.def: in trouble with the police

idioms.idiom: the other side of the coin
idioms.def: the aspect of a situation that is the opposite of or contrasts with the one you have been talking about
with the top part turned to the top; in the correct, normal position
examples: I dropped my toast, but luckily it fell right side up.

idioms.def: close together and facing in the same direction
examples: There were two children ahead, walking side by side.
The two sat side by side on the bench.
We have been using both systems, side by side, for two years.
The two communities exist happily side by side.

idioms.def: used to refer to either of two opposite opinions on an issue
examples: The two countries are often on opposite sides of the fence when it comes to climate change.
There are arguments on both sides of the aisle.
On the other side of the fence there is anger at the reforms.
It is a proposal approved by people on both sides of the political fence.

idioms.def: to laugh a lot at somebody/something
to express support for somebody in an argument
examples: She didn't think it was wise to take sides in their argument.

idioms.def: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something
before a particular time, event, age, etc.
examples: They aren't likely to arrive this side of midnight.

idioms.def: a person or thing that repeatedly annoys somebody or stops them from doing something
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something

idioms.idiom: two sides of the same coin
idioms.def: used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation
